A layer of an epoxy resin, type MTM59 (from AGC), was coated on a "120 style" fiberglass fabric to form the prepreg. The nominal resin content of the prepreg was 44% by weight. The prepreg stored and remained frozen at 0°F (-17.8°C), and was thawed just prior to fabricating a base sleeve.

The prepreg was placed on an X-Y cutting table, which allowed a more precise cutting dimension than cutting by hand. Once at room temperature, the prepreg was unrolled on an X-Y cutting table, and each of three sheets was cut to have at least one non-linear edge that will form an axial seam of the base sleeve. To achieve the desired strength and flexibility, three layers of prepreg were used to fabricate the base sleeve. Cutting patterns for the three pieces of prepreg were created as instructed by the manufacturer of the cutting table vendor. The shape of all three sheets was similar, with only a slight change in length to account for diameter change as additional layers were added. The pattern described as follows was repeated across the width of each piece. For this example, the width of the finished print form was 50 inches (127 cm). The first sheet was cut to have a non-linear edge on the lead end that appears as a zigzag pattern of repeating waves; in which each wave has a period of 5 inch (12.7) valley-to-valley (see FIG. 3, period 48) and amplitude of 0.2 inch (0.508 cm) measured perpendicular from peak to valley (see FIG. 3, amplitude 46). The second end of the first sheet was cut to have the same zigzag pattern of repeating waves as the first end, except that the start of the zigzag pattern on the first end is offset (out of phase) with the zigzag on the second end by 1.25 inch (3.175 cm). Each sheet was cut to a length as measured from a midpoint of the amplitude of the first end and a midpoint of the amplitude of the second end of each sheet. The first sheet was cut to length of 20.180 inch (51.26 cm). The second sheet was cut to length of 20.217 inch (51.35 cm). The third sheet was cut to length of 20.255 inch (51.45 cm).

For this example, the base sleeves were fabricated to fit on a 6.435 inch (16.235 cm) diameter print cylinder, which is a standard quarter-pitch size in the printing industry. The base sleeve was formed around a cylindrical aluminum mandrel which has a diameter of 6.424 inches (16.317 cm); smaller than the diameter of the print cylinder because the mandrel expands during the thermal cycle required to cure the epoxy. The mandrel was prepared in a fashion typical in the composites industry with both a mold sealant and mold release prior to forming the base sleeve. The mandrel was the inner half of the mold that forms the base sleeve.

The zigzag pattern of the lead edge of the sheet forming Ply 1 was aligned axially along the length of the mandrel. Once aligned, the sheet was wrapped around the mandrel. The length of each ply was defined such that the resulting seam of the first end/second end, i.e., lead edge/trail edge, appears as shown in Figure 3. In Figure 3, the trail edge is shaded for identification. Since the zigzag on the lead edge was offset (out of phase) with the zigzag on the trail edge, the lead edge and the trail edge of the wrapped sheet formed an axial seam having alternating regions of overlap (i.e., contacting portions) and under lap (i.e., gap portions). The width of the under lap and the overlap were both about 0.1 inches (0.254 cm). The type of X-Y cutting table and the roll forming equipment used to wrap the prepreg around the mandrel were selected such that the variation is less than +/-0.1 inches (+/-0.254 cm) so that there are always regions of overlap and under lap.

The wrapping process was repeated individually for the second sheet forming Ply 2 and for the third sheet forming Ply 3 with the location of the respective seams spaced 120° apart around the circumference of the mandrel as shown in Figure 5. After all three layers of prepreg were applied, multiple layers of a film tape were then wrapped around the 3 plies on the mandrel using a tape wrapping machine that is typical in the prepreg roll-forming industry. The tape was the outer half of the mold that forms the base sleeve. The taped mandrel was hung in a vertical oven and cured using the thermal cycle defined by ACG for the MTM59 epoxy resin system.

After cooling, the tape was removed and the tube slid off the mandrel. The fiberglass/epoxy composite tube had a 0.13 inch (0.33 cm) wall thickness that was suitable as a base sleeve and ready for application of the photopolymer. For simplicity, the base sleeve of the Example having seams formed of a non-linear edge with an amplitude and overlapping portions, is referred to as a zigzag pattern or zigzag seam.

For comparison purposes, similar base sleeves were made with straight seams. For the base sleeve of Comparative A, the length of each ply was increased by 0.020 inches (0.051 cm) to force the seams to have a nominal overlap, i.e., completely overlap leading end and trailing end along length of the seam. For the base sleeve of Comparative B, the length of each ply was decreased by 0.020 inches (0.051 cm) to force a nominal under lap, i.e., forming a gap between leading end and trailing end along the length of the seam. Such seams would be typical of a fabrication process for seams in which the lead and trail edges are intended to perfectly abut each other since typical manufacturing tolerances will result in variation. All other fabrication and processing parameters remained the same.

The base sleeve was mounted with air-assist onto a mandrel for preparing a cylindrically shaped photopolymerizable form. A CYREL® photopolymerizable material, type HORB® (from DuPont, Wilmington, DE, USA), was applied to the base sleeve as a molten material and calendered as described in US Patents 5,916,403 and US 5798,019.. Once cooled to room temperature, the nominal thickness of the photopolymerizable layer was 0.049 inches (0.124 cm). The photopolymerizable material is a composition that includes an elastomeric binder, monomer, photoinitiator, and additives, as is well-known to those of ordinary skill in the art. The photopolymerizable layer was calendered for a time sufficient such that a seamless photopolymerizable layer was formed on the base sleeve, i.e., the photopolymerizable layer was shaped into a uniform cylindrical layer surrounding the base sleeve. While the above method was used to form the cylindrical photopolymerizable layer on the base sleeve, the photopolymerizable material could be applied to the base sleeve by any other method known by those skilled in the art of cylindrical printing forms for flexography.

An infrared-radiation-sensitive, actinic-radiation-opaque layer as described in US. Patent 6,238,837 was applied to the exterior surface of the cylindrical photopolymerizable layer by coating with the process as described in US Patent 6,531,184.

A cylindrical precursor composed of the base sleeve, the cylindrical layer of the photopolymerizable material, and the infrared layer was converted to a cylindrical printing form. An in-situ mask was formed by laser ablation of the infrared sensitive layer on the precursor using a CYREL® Digital Imager. The in-situ mask image was a target that included solids, line work, and various screen areas (5, 15, 30, 50, 70%) at 133 lines per inch (52.36 lines per cm). The screen areas of the mask covered the entire circumference of the print form and thus overlapped each of the three seams to accentuate any print defect caused by a seam.

The cylindrical precursor was exposed through the base sleeve on a custommade exposure unit to ultraviolet radiation at 365nm for an overall exposure through the base sleeve for 52 seconds. Then, the cylindrical precursor was imagewise exposed through the in-situ mask in air for six minutes using an exposure unit for cylindrical print forms as described in US patent publication US 2010/0321663 A1. The photosensitive elements were processed in a CYREL® solvent development apparatus using CYREL® Cylosol solvent developer at the conditions recommended for precursors having a 0.049 inch (0.124 cm) photopolymeric layer. The cylindrical precursor was developed to reach the relief depth of 0.018 inch (0.046 cm) forming the cylindrical printing form having a relief surface on the photopolymer layer that was suitable for printing. The cylindrical printing form from the precursor was post exposed and light-finished on a CYREL® Round Light-Finisher unit.

heading.u: Printing of the Cylindrical Printing Form

description.p: The thus prepared cylindrical printing form was used to print images onto 1.5 mil white linear low density polyethylene mono-layer, one side treated substrate that was 40 inches (101.6 cm) wide. The cylindrical printing form was mounted with air assist onto a printing cylinder of a Paper Converting Machine Company (PCMC) Avanti central impression, 8 color, gearless, cantilevered press. A Harper 800/2.1 anilox roll was used to ink the cylindrical printing form with a cyan solvent flexographic ink (manufactured by Sun Chemical, order code DRSFS5133195 /K525 PROCESS GS CYAN). Printing was done at 500 feet per minute (2.54 metres per second), at both a "Kiss" and a "Kiss plus 0.002 inch" impression. Although the cylindrical print forms were 50 inches (127 cm) wide, the actual image was 34 inches (86.36 cm) and centered on the substrate. No problems with the compressed air mounting and dismounting of the printing forms of the Example and Comparatives were observed.

Two observers reviewed the print samples independently, each under different viewing conditions and noted the location of print defects that were detected by eye. The locations of the defects were compared to the actual location of the seams in the base sleeve, which could be determined by looking at the seams. The table below contains the defect counts that were associated with seams of the printing form for each observer.
Seam TypeObserver #1Observer #2Total
ExampleZigzag101
Comparative AOverlap145
Comparative BUnder lap314

Observer #1 detected the fewest number of print defects associated with the base sleeve of the Example (zigzag pattern seam) and with the base sleeve of Comparative A (overlap seam). Observer #2 detected the least amount of print defects for the base sleeve of the Example. When the results are combined, the base sleeve of the Example having the zigzag seams, that is, seams with overlapping portions and non-contacting portions, showed significantly fewer print defects than the base sleeve of Comparative A having straight overlapped seams, and the base sleeve of Comparative B having straight gapped seams. Although the discontinuous seams of the base sleeve of the Example can be observed in the cylindrical printing form, their presence did not interfere with the exposure through the base sleeve to form the floor of the relief pattern, nor print through to the printed image.

claim.claim-text: Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, wobei der Aufbringschritt eine kontinuierliche Lage (65) des bebilderbaren, die Naht bedeckenden Materials bildet.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, wobei das Material ein Verbundstoffmaterial ist, das ein faseriges Material und ein aushärtbares Harz umfasst.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, wobei das Material ein Verbundstoffmaterial ist, das ein Textilstoffmaterial und ein wärmeaushärtbares Harz umfasst.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, wobei die Naht (30) eine diskontinuierliche Naht ist, die den Überlappungsteil (32) und einen oder mehrere Lückenteile (36) zwischen dem ersten Ende(14) und dem zweiten Ende (24) umfasst.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, wobei die Naht (30) einen oder mehrere Überlappungsteile (32) und einen oder mehrere nichtkontaktierende Teile umfasst, die eine Lücke zwischen dem ersten Ende (14) und dem zweiten Ende (24) bilden.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, wobei der Aufrollschritt das Positionieren der Platte auf eine zylinderförmige Auflage und das Rotieren der Auflage umfasst, um das zweite Ende (24) an des erste Ende (14) anliegend zu bringen.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, wobei die nichtlineare Kante eine Wellenform einer Mehrzahl von Wellen umfasst, wobei jede Welle eine Amplitude aufweist, die gleich oder verschieden sein kann.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, wobei die nichtlineare Kante eine Wellenform einer Mehrzahl von Wellen umfasst, wobei jede Welle eine Periodenbreite aufweist, die gleich oder verschieden sein kann.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, wobei die Naht (30) eine axiale Naht des zweiten Endes in Kontakt mit mindestens einem Teil der Amplitude der nichtlinearen Kante ist.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, wobei das zweite Ende (24) eine lineare Kante bildet.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, wobei das zweite Ende (24) eine nichtlineare Kante bildet, die eine Amplitude aufweist, die von der Amplitude des ersten Endes verschieden ist.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, wobei die nichtlineare Kante eine Wellenform einer Mehrzahl von Wellen umfasst, wobei jede Welle eine Amplitude und eine Periodenbreite aufweist, die gleich sind, und das zweite Ende eine nichtlineare Kante aufweist, die eine Wellenform einer Mehrzahl von Wellen umfasst, wobei jede Welle eine Amplitude und eine Periodenbreite aufweist, die gleich wie oder verschieden von der Amplitude und Periodenbreite des ersten Endes sind.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 13, wobei die Periode der Mehrzahl von Wellen des zweiten Endes unkoordiniert mit der Periode der Mehrzahl von Wellen des ersten Endes ist.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, wobei 15 bis 90 % des ersten Endes (14) überlappende Teile (32) mit dem zweiten Ende (24) bilden.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, wobei die Amplitude eine Höhe aufweist, die gleich wie oder größer als eine Druckbreite ist, die in einem Spalt zwischen der Druckform, die auf einen Druckzylinder montiert ist, und einer Druckwalze auf einer Druckerpresse gebildet wird.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, des Weiteren vor dem Aufbringschritt c) folgendes umfassend: bi) das Aufrollen einer zusätzliche Platte eines Materials, das ein erstes Ende und ein zweites Ende aufweist, auf die Außenfläche (66) der Auflagehülse aufweist, um das zweite Ende nahe an das erste Ende der zusätzlichen Platte zu bringen, um eine Naht (30) der zusätzlichen Platte zu bilden, wobei das erste Ende der zusätzlichen Platte eine nichtlineare Kante bildet, die eine Amplitude aufweist und Teile des zweiten Endes der zusätzliche Platte überlappt.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 17, wobei die Naht (30) der ersten Platte eine axiale Naht ist und die Naht der zusätzlichen Platte im Umfang von der axialen Naht versetzt ist.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 17, wobei die Auflagehülse (10) eine axiale Länge aufweist und des Weiteren das Versetzen in der Länge einer axialen Position mindestens eines der überlappenden Teile an der Naht der zusätzlichen Platte von einer axialen Position des überlappenden Teils der Naht der ersten Platte umfasst.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 17, des Weiteren das Wiederholen des Schritt bi) mit einer oder mehreren zusätzlichen Platten Material auf eine Außenfläche der vorher aufgerollten Platte.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, des Weiteren vor dem Aufbringungsschritt c) folgendes umfassend: das Wickeln einer entfernbaren Folie um die Außenfläche der Auflagehülse, Erhitzen, um das Material auszuhärten, und Entfernen der Folie.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 21, wobei die entfernbare Folie eine Schrumpffolie ist.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, wobei das bebilderbare Material ein photoempfindliches Material umfasst.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, wobei das bebilderbare Material eine photopolymerisierbare Zusammensetzung eines elastomeren Bindemittels, mindestens eine ethylenisch ungesättigte Verbindung und einen Photoinitiator umfasst.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, des Weiteren nach Schritt c) folgendes umfassend: das Bilden einer Druckfläche aus der Lage des bebilderbaren Materials; und das Montieren der Druckform auf einen Druckzylinder einer Druckerpresse; wobei die Amplitude eine Höhe aufweist, die gleich wie oder größer als die Druckbreite ist, die in einem Spalt zwischen der Druckform und einer Druckwalze auf der Druckerpresse gebildet wird.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, des Weiteren vor dem Aufbringschritt c) folgendes umfassend: das Modifizieren der Außenfläche (66) der Auflagehülse (10) durch eine Modifikationsbehandlung ausgewählt unter Aufbringen eines Klebstoffmaterials, Mahlen oder Kiesstrahlen.
The method of Claim 1 wherein the applying step forms a continuous layer (65) of the imageable material covering the seam.
The method of Claim 1 wherein the material is a composite material comprising a fibrous material and a curable resin.
The method of Claim 1 wherein the material is a composite material comprising a fabric material and a thermally-curable resin.
The method of Claim 1 wherein the seam (30) is a discontinuous seam comprising the overlap portion (32) and one or more gap portions (36) between the first end (14) and the second end (24).

The method of Claim 1 wherein the seam (30) comprises one or more of the overlap portions (32) and one or more non-contacting portions that form a gap between the first end (14) and the second end (24).
The method of Claim 1 wherein the wrapping step comprises placing the sheet onto a cylindrically-shaped support and rotating the support to bring the second end (24) and the first end (14) adjacent.
The method of Claim 1 wherein the non-linear edge comprises a waveform of a plurality of waves, each wave having an amplitude which can be the same or different.
The method of Claim 1 wherein the non-linear edge comprises a waveform of a plurality of waves, each wave having a period width which can be the same or different.
The method of Claim 1 wherein the seam (30) is an axial seam of the second end in contact with at least a portion of the amplitude of the non-linear edge.
The method of Claim 1 wherein the second end (24) forms a linear edge.
The method of Claim 1 wherein the second end (24) forms a non-linear edge having an amplitude that is different from the amplitude of the first end.

The method of Claim 1 wherein the non-linear edge comprises a waveform of a plurality of waves, each wave having an amplitude and a period width which are the same, and the second end has a non-linear edge comprising a waveform of a plurality of waves, each wave having an amplitude and a period that are the same or different as the amplitude and period of the first end.
The method of Claim 13 wherein the period of the plurality of waves of the second end is out of phase with the period of the plurality of waves of the first end.
The method of Claim 1 wherein 15 to 90% of the first end (14) forms overlapping portions (32) with the second end (24).

The method of Claim 1 wherein the amplitude has a height equal to or greater than a print width that is created at a nip between the printing form mounted on a printing cylinder and an impression roll on a print press.

The method of Claim 1 further comprising, prior to the applying step c): bi) wrapping an additional sheet of a material having a first end and a second end onto the exterior surface (66) of the base sleeve to bring the second end adjacent the first end of the additional sheet to form a seam (30) of the additional sheet, wherein the first end of the additional sheet forms a non-linear edge that has an amplitude and overlaps portions of the second end of the additional sheet.
The method of Claim 17 wherein the seam (30) of the first sheet is an axial seam and the seam of the additional sheet is circumferentially offset from the axial seam.

The method of Claim 17 wherein the base sleeve (10) has an axial length and further comprises offsetting on the length an axial position of at least one of the overlap portions at the seam of the additional sheet from an axial position of the overlap portion of the seam of the first sheet.
The method of Claim 17 further comprising repeating step bi) with one or more additional sheets of material on to an exterior surface of the previously wrapped sheet.
The method of Claim 1 further comprising prior to the applying step c): wrapping a removable film about the exterior surface of the base sleeve, heating to cure the material, and removing the film.
The method of Claim 21 wherein the removable film is a shrink-wrap film.
The method of Claim 1 wherein the imageable material comprises a photosensitive material.
The method of Claim 1 wherein the imageable material comprises a photopolymerizable composition of an elastomeric binder, at least one ethylenically unsaturated compound, and a photoinitiator.

The method of Claim 1 further comprising after step c): forming a printing surface from the layer of the imageable material; and mounting the printing form onto a printing cylinder of a print press; wherein the amplitude has a height equal to or greater than print width created at a nip between the printing form and an impression roll on the print press.

The method of Claim 1 further comprising, prior to applying step c): modifying the exterior surface (66) of the base sleeve (10) with a modification treatment selected from applying an adhesive material, grinding, or grit blasting.
Procédé selon la revendication 1 dans lequel l'étape d'application forme une couche continue (65) du matériau pouvant être imagé recouvrant le joint.
Procédé selon la revendication 1 dans lequel le matériau est un matériau composite comprenant un matériau fibreux et une résine durcissable.
Procédé selon la revendication 1 dans lequel le matériau est un matériau composite comprenant un matériau textile et une résine thermiquement durcissable.

Procédé selon la revendication 1 dans lequel le joint (30) est un joint discontinu comprenant la portion chevauchante (32) et une ou plusieurs portion(s) d'espace (36) entre la première extrémité (14) et la seconde extrémité (24).

Procédé selon la revendication 1 dans lequel le joint (30) comprend une ou plusieurs des portions chevauchantes (32) et une ou plusieurs portion(s) non en contact qui forment un espace entre la première extrémité (14) et la seconde extrémité (24).

Procédé selon la revendication 1 dans lequel l'étape d'enroulement comprend la mise en place de la feuille sur un support de forme cylindrique et la rotation du support pour porter la seconde extrémité (24) et la première extrémité (14) l'une contre l'autre.
Procédé selon la revendication 1 dans lequel le bord non linéaire comprend une forme d'onde d'une pluralité d'ondes, chaque onde ayant une amplitude qui peut être identique ou différente.
Procédé selon la revendication 1 dans lequel le bord non linéaire comprend une forme d'onde d'une pluralité d'ondes, chaque onde ayant une largeur de période qui peut être identique ou différente.
Procédé selon la revendication 1 dans lequel le joint (30) est un joint axial de la seconde extrémité en contact avec au moins une portion de l'amplitude du bord non linéaire.
Procédé selon la revendication 1 dans lequel la seconde extrémité (24) forme un bord linéaire.
Procédé selon la revendication 1 dans lequel la seconde extrémité (24) forme un bord non linéaire ayant une amplitude qui est différente de l'amplitude de la première extrémité.

Procédé selon la revendication 1 dans lequel le bord non linéaire comprend une forme d'onde d'une pluralité d'ondes, chaque onde ayant une amplitude et une largeur de période qui sont identiques, et la seconde extrémité a un bord non linéaire comprenant une forme d'onde d'une pluralité d'ondes, chaque onde ayant une amplitude et une largeur de période qui sont identiques ou différentes de l'amplitude et de la largeur de période de la première extrémité.

Procédé selon la revendication 13 dans lequel la période de la pluralité d'ondes de la seconde extrémité se trouve hors phase par rapport à la période de la pluralité des ondes de la première extrémité.
Procédé selon la revendication 1 dans lequel 15 à 90 % de la première extrémité (14) forme des portions chevauchantes (32) avec la seconde extrémité (24).

Procédé selon la revendication 1 dans lequel l'amplitude a une hauteur supérieure ou égale à une largeur d'impression qui est créée à un resserrement entre la forme d'impression montée sur un cylindre d'impression et un cylindre d'impression sur une presse d'impression.

Procédé selon la revendication 1 comprenant en outre, avant l'étape d'application c): bi) l'enroulement d'une feuille supplémentaire d'un matériau ayant une première extrémité et une seconde extrémité sur la surface extérieure (66) du manchon de base pour porter la seconde extrémité de manière adjacente à la première extrémité de la feuille supplémentaire pour former un joint (30) de la feuille supplémentaire, dans lequel la première extrémité de la feuille supplémentaire forme un bord non linéaire qui a une amplitude et qui chevauche des portions de la seconde extrémité de la feuille supplémentaire.

Procédé selon la revendication 17 dans lequel le joint (30) de la première feuille est un joint axial et le joint de la feuille supplémentaire est en décalage dans la circonférence par rapport au joint axial.

Procédé selon la revendication 17 dans lequel le manchon de base (10) a une longueur axiale et comprend en outre un décalage sur la longueur d'une position axiale d'au moins l'une des portions chevauchantes au niveau du joint de la feuille supplémentaire à partir d'une position axiale de la portion chevauchante du joint de la première feuille.

Procédé selon la revendication 17 comprenant en outre l'étape de répétition bi) avec une ou plusieurs feuille(s) supplémentaire(s) du matériau sur une surface externe de la feuille précédemment enroulée.

Procédé selon la revendication 1 comprenant en outre avant l'étape d'application c): l'enroulement d'un film amovible autour de la surface externe du manchon de base, le chauffage pour durcir le matériau, et le retrait du film.
Procédé selon la revendication 21 dans lequel le film amovible est un film d'emballage rétrécissable.
Procédé selon la revendication 1 dans lequel le matériau pouvant être imagé comprend un matériau photosensible.

Procédé selon la revendication 1 dans lequel le matériau pouvant être imagé comprend une composition photopolymérisable d'un liant élastomère, au moins un composé éthyléniquement insaturé, et un photoinitiateur.

Procédé selon la revendication 1 comprenant en outre après l'étape c): la formation d'une surface d'impression à partir de la couche du matériau pouvant être imagé; et le montage de la forme d'impression sur un cylindre d'impression d'une presse d'impression; dans lequel l'amplitude a une hauteur égale à ou supérieure à la largeur d'impression créée à un rétrécissement entre la forme d'impression et un rouleau d'impression sur la presse d'impression.

Procédé selon la revendication 1 comprenant en outre, avant l'étape d'application c): la modification de la surface externe (66) du manchon de base (10) par un traitement de modification sélectionné parmi l'application d'un matériau adhésif, le broyage ou le sablage.
